config.question: How did the rise of the assemblies in the 1700s affect colonial political culture?

choices.content: Colonial legal practices more closely resembled those of England.
Women were given voting rights and adequate representation in Parliament.
The assemblies became replicas of the British House of Commons.
The colonies were brought under direct control of the king, and governors lost power.

answer_3.response: Consider This: English courts and councils scrutinized legislative actions from all thirteen mainland colonies. Elected members of the colonial assemblies believed that they had an obligation to preserve colonial liberties. They perceived any attack on the legislature as an assault on the rights of Americans. See L.O. 4.4 Why were the eighteenth-century colonial assemblies not fully democratic?
